oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ogden house
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ogden house. Women and children on porch and in yard; two people on horseback in street. From Hall and Stakely family pictures. (damaged). Submitted ID: Ca. 1878. The house of James R. Ogden, president of Knoxville Iron Co. He is the one who is listed at #303 Broad in the 1890 City Directory. The house does look ca. 1880s. In 1895, Elise P. Ogden is listed there (as widowed). She's still there in 1900. James and Elise Ogden had seven children: William Porta 1867-1880 Adele Helene 1869 Elise Luch 1870 James Francis 1872 Mary 1874 Ansel Robinson 1876 (Nov) Richard William 1879
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Houses; Horses; Families;

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Carte-de-visite (CDV) of Horace Maynard (1814-1882), a lawyer in East Tennessee. Hayes.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Scenes in the Mining Regions of Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Singleton & McFarland, Photographers, 257 Gay Street, Knoxville, Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scenes in the Mining Regions of Tenn. From original negatives by Singleton & McFarland, Photographers, 257 Gay Street, Knoxville, TN’. List on back: photographs of ‘Groups we have taken at Briceville, Coal Creek, Fort Anderson and Camp Carnes. Number circled on back is 671: Queen City Guards on Walden’s Ridge.’ Photograph shows young men in military uniform seated and standing outdoors, holding rifles. East Tennessee conflict between coal miners and the convict-lease system was in 1891. The state militia was called in by the Governor.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mining; Military personnel; Military uniforms; Rifles; Coal mining;

oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: At the height of the logging boom, over 200 miles of railroad snaked through the mountains. Geared locomotives, such as the Shay engine, pulled heavy loads through the steep and winding terrain. Portable steam-powered machines, such as the Clyde Overhead Skidder and the Surrey Parker, made loading and moving large logs by rail much easier and safer. Large lumber mills and company towns were built at Crestmont on Big Creek; Smokemont on the Oconoluftee River; Ravensford on Raven Fork; Townsend on the Little River; and Proctor on Hazel Creek, among others. The logging itself was done from portable camps, which moved from site to site as needed. The books Dorie by Florence Cope Bush and Last Train to Elkmont by Vic Weals movingly document what life was like in the lumber camps of the Little River. Logging continued on much of the land acquired for the park. In 1939, the Little River Lumber Company hauled its last load of logs from the mountains to its mill in Townsend. Over 60 percent of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park had been logged by 1940, when the park was dedicated.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lonas. Henry Lonas home.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Henry Lonas home on Western Avenue, Knoxville, TN. It was used as a stage coach stop known as "Four-Mile House." It was built of hand made brick and was located on Western Avenue just east of New Gray Cemetery. The house was torn down in 1938. Submitted ID: 'Mellen House' --Kingston Pike at Forks of the River. Built 1835, torn down for Western Plaza Shopping Center. from "Historic Treasure Spots of Knox County, Tennessee."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Keyhill. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Keyhill.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Keyhill. In 1857 Richard Keyhill (born ca. 1802) and other residents of South Knoxville formed a Sunday School in the Cedar Hill community of Knox County, TN. In December 1860 this group was organized as the Cedar Ridge Baptist Church. In the late 1860s it was renamed the Holston Baptist Church and in 1882 it was located on land donated by Perez Dickinson and was renamed Island Home Baptist church (or the Baptist Church at Island Home).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Human Fly," George Gibson Polley, 1918
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ross Hahn
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The "Human Fly," George Gibson Polley, shown climbing the Burwell Building on the corner of Gay Street and Clinch Avenue, Knoxville, TN. He climbed all ten stories of the building, stood on his head at the top of the building, and then scaled the flagpole. Mr. Polley, also known as "The Original Human Fly" was from Marblehead, MA. Account of the climb in the Knoxville Journal, April 7, 1918. The stunt was probably in conjunction with the Great Liberty Parade in downtown Knoxville. Ross Hahn photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Climbing; Stunt performers; Events;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Great Liberty Parade, Knoxville, TN, April 1918
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ross Hahn
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Great Liberty Parade on Gay Street, Knoxville, TN. 6,000 march in line forty city blocks long with crowd of 25,000. Largest parade staged in Knoxville with 150 banners and floats. Marking the anniversary of the entry into the War (World War One, WWI) and the launching of the third loan drive. An account of the parade is in the Knoxville Journal, April 7, 1918. Streetcar in foreground. George Gibson Polley, the "Human Fly," seen standing on building corner at left. Ross Hahn photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Events; Parades & processions; Street railroads; War bonds & funds;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Baker-Himel parade postcard, 1907
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: JET [James E. Thompson]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard printed caption: ‘Third Regiment N.C.S.T. band and Baker-Himel students passing [Knox County, TN] Court House. Baker-Himel school stood 96 dry and 4 wet’. (Handwritten note: ’ =100.’ ‘ Studio - X-hall door. Notice piano in ball room 2nd floor.’ ‘This is interesting showing some street corner or other. The wrecked building is Woman’s Bldg where my studio was.’ Real photo postcard (RPPC) . Postmarked Nov. 1, 1907. Temperance parade was March 1907. Addressed to Clyde O. DeLand, Philadelphia, PA. Taken at the corner of Main Street and Gay Street, Knoxville, TN. Destroyed building in background was the Woman’s Building which burned December 26, 1906 (streetcar barn later occupied that site). Frank Carpenter, Livery, Board & Sales, Stables signs on building to left of ruins. Also pictured: Magnolia streetcar, parade with band members and school group with sign.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Postcards; Events; Temperance; Parades & processions; Bands; Schools; Street railroads;

Ca. 1910 the business was in 7 Market House and he went into partnership with E.M. Atkinson.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Blue-Gray Reunion , 1890
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Reunion of the Blue and the Gray in Knoxville, TN, October 8-9, 1890. Allegedly the first joint meeting of the Civil War Union and Confederate veterans ever held. The photograph was taken from the roof of the J.D. Cowan house near Cumberland Avenue, near the site of present day Sophronia Strong Hall on the University of Tennessee campus. The tent seen at left was the "Monster Tent" which could seat 15,000. It was erected near the edge of the remains of Fort Sanders, a Civil War site.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Reunions; Tents; Battlefields; Forts & fortifications;

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dickson - Williams house in Greeneville, TN. On back of photograph: "It was here that General Morgan was killed" (in 1864). Construction of the house began in 1815. It was originally the home of Greeneville's first postmaster, William Dickson. His daughter, Catherine Dickson, married Dr. Alexander Williams and they lived in the house.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: McClung. Hugh Lawson McClung.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Knaffl & Bro., Knoxville, TN
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hugh Lawson McClung. Son of Matthew and Eliza J. (Morgan) McClung. Born December 24, 1839 in Knoxville, TN. Served as Captain of Company F, 26th Regiment Tennessee Volunteers, Confederate States Army (CSA), Civil War. He was killed at the battle of Fort Donaldson (sic.) (Donelson) on February 15, 1862, while leading his company. He was buried in Old Gray Cemetery, Knoxville,TN. This photograph was by Knaffl & Bro. from an 1861 Daguerreotype.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Headquarters, Department of the Gulf
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Edwards & Son, Atlanta, GA
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mounted panoramic photograph, ‘Headquarters, Department of the Gulf.’ Sepia. Edwards & Son, Atlanta, GA. Photograph is 8.5 x 19.25” mounted on 11.5 x 22” board. Shows group of man, women and children posed in front of building [Leydon House] at 198 Peachtree Street, Atlanta, GA. The Department of the Gulf moved in the building in 1903; the building was razed in 1913. Many are wearing ribbons or badges. On front row, one African American (or someone dressed to look African American) with hair in scarf and wearing a sign ‘All Samee, Me Likee, CLAUBER, No Leekee.’ The extreme left and right edges are not shown in this image; the original print was too long for the scanner.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Panoramic photographs; Group portraits;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Harriman's first football team, 1891
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Harriman's first football team, 1891. They played a group of young men from Knoxville and University of Tennessee students on Thanksgiving Day 1891 in Knoxville. Harriman won the game 14 to 4. This is credited with being the first organized football game ever played in Knoxville. Harriman team captain was W.C. Spicer, the player with a mustache holding the ball. To his left is Harry Durrell. The others in the photograph are unidentified. At far left is an African American man holding a white flag or pennant with an ‘H’ on it. At the far right is a man in a top hat and dress coat. Harriman is in Roane County, TN.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Football players; Football; Group portraits; Uniforms; African Americans;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jacques & McCall tintype, ca. 1891
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tintype of Samuel Foster Jacques (right) and University of Tennessee Professor McCall (McColl?). Ca. 1891-92. Samuel Foster Jacques grew up in Newburyport, MA, the son of Edmund Jacques and Rachel A. Foster Jacques. In 1893 he married Abbie Parish Noyes. He died on January 8, 1916 in a motorcycle accident. J.R. McColl was Assistant Professor of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville from 1896-1902.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portraits; Tintypes;

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summer School of the South, Knoxville, TN, Tenth Session, June 20-July 28, 1911. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1871 Bird's-eye view of Knoxville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bird's Eye View of the City of Knoxville, Knox County, Tennessee. Looking northwest. 1871. Lower left: East Tennessee University. References: 1. Court House 2. County Jail 3. E.T. University 4. Asylum for the Deaf & Dumb 5. Market House 6. City Hall 7. Knoxville & Kentucky RR Depot 8. E.T. GA & VA RR Depot 9. Gray Cemetery 10. National Cemetery. Churches: 11. Baptist 12. Episcopal 13. Lutheran 14. Methodist 15. 1st Presbyterian 16. 2nd Presbyterian 17 Catholic 1. Female Institute. Also available, a larger Photostat copy of the map cataloged as Maps: 912.7688 1871 Aerial View.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Friends Normal School
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: J. Peden & Co. Maryville, Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Friends Normal School group in snow. Ca. 1890s. The building was originally built as the home of Dr. Samuel Pride of Maryville. During the Civil War General Sherman used the building as his headquarters, Dec. 5-6, 1863. In 1878 to 1901 the building was used for the Friends Normal and Preparatory School. The building was demolished in 1910. Photograph taken by J. Peden & Co. Maryville, Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Schools; School children; Group portraits; Snow;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Walker. Cas Walker.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photograph by Tom Greene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cas Walker (left) and J.S. Cooper fist fight at a Knoxville City Council meeting March 1956 (Closeup). The photograph appeared in the March 19, 1956 issue of Life Magazine. The photograph was taken by Tom Greene and is used with the permission of his family. Cas Walker was elected Mayor of Knoxville in 1946, but was removed in a recall election shortly afterwards. He was elected to the Knoxville City Council in 1947 and served until 1971. Seated, l-r: James Walls, Mayor John J. Duncan. Portrait on wall at lower left is Mayor George S. Dempster.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Fighting; Politicians;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.

The photograph was taken by Tom Greene and is used with the permission of his family. Cas Walker was elected Mayor of Knoxville in 1946, but was removed in a recall election shortly afterwards. He was elected to the Knoxville City Council in 1947 and served until 1971. Seated, l-r: James Walls, Mayor John J. Duncan, man with cigar is Hobart Carey. Portrait on wall at lower left is Mayor George S. Dempster.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Walker. Cas Walker.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photograph by Tom Greene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cas Walker (left) and J.S. Cooper standing third from left with cigarette, at a Knoxville City Council meeting March 1956. Taken either shortly before or after a fist fight between the two men. The photograph was taken by Tom Greene and is used with the permission of his family. Cas Walker was elected Mayor of Knoxville in 1946, but was removed in a recall election shortly afterwards. He was elected to the Knoxville City Council in 1947 and served until 1971. Seated, l-r: James Walls, Mayor John J. Duncan.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sirenius M. Mort tintype_001
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Civil War tintype of Sirenius M. Mort, 1st Lt., Co. F, 9th Tennessee Cavalry Volunteers, U.S.A. Lt. Mort is pictured seated, holding a sword. There is some tinting on the tintype; the belt buckle, buttons and bars on the uniform are highlighted in gold and the sash is colored purple or dark red. Housed in a Daguerreotype Union Case made by Littlefield, Parsons & Co. The case is embossed with an eagle and the U.S. flag. A newspaper obituary for Lt. Mort was found folded in the case. He died on July 15, 1869. He was a member of a well known family of potters in Jefferson County, TN.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sirenius M. Mort tintype_003
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Civil War tintype of Sirenius M. Mort, 1st Lt., Co. F, 9th Tennessee Cavalry Volunteers, U.S.A. A newspaper obituary for Lt. Mort was found folded in the case. He died on July 15, 1869. Newspaper obituary from Dandridge, TN, July 16, 1869.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Funeral rites & ceremonies;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tribute of Respects. Dandridge, July 16, 1869. On the morning of yesterday, Lieut. S. Mort, late of Co. F, 9th Tennessee Cavalry Volunteers, went to his work in ordinary health, at 2 o'clock of that day he was a corpse. Lt. M. was dangerously sick but about two hours—during which time he was insensible. His death was caused by sun-stroke. The ex-soldiers of this place and vicinity attended the funeral to-day in a body, and immediately after the burial services gathered at the court house where the following proceedings were had. On motion, D. R. N. Blackburn, Esq., was called to the chair, and W. M. Hill elected secretary. The chairman, in obedience to the instructions of the meeting, appointed a committee of five to draft resolutions expressive of our feelings of respect and regard towards the deceased. The committee reported the following which were unanimously adopted: Whereas, It pleased the Good Father and Great Captain to call from time to eternity, suddenly, and in a most unexpected manner, on yesterday, the 15th inst., our soldier-brother and comrade, 1st. Lieut. Sirenius M. Mort, therefore be it resolved, 1 st. That the deceased Lieut. Mort, was a brave, patriotic and model soldier, that he justly had the esteem and warm friendship of all his associates in the army, and that in consequence of his uniform kindness to those whom he commanded, he was throughout his entire term of service one of the most popular of officers. 2d. As a citizen the deceased was industrious, generous, and an honor to his country. 3d. As a husband, brother, and son, Lt. Mort was faithful, affectionate, and "the light of the household.'' 4th. That we commend the character and conduct of our departed brother, and pledge ourselves to ever keep his memory green; and we tender to the greatly afflicted family and relatives of Lt. Mort, the ardent sympathy of old soldiers and true friends. 5th. That the officers of this meeting furnish to the widow of Lt. Mort, a copy of our proceedings, and also that they furnish copies for publication to the Knovville (sic.) Whig, and Press and Herald. Upon motion the meeting adjourned without day, D. R. N. Blackburn, Ch'n. W. M. Hill, Sec'y.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Looking towards Tennessee from Clingman’s Dome (stereograph)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: SV 2012.001b (back): 37570 Looking towards Tennessee from Clingman’s Dome, Great Smoky National Park, North Carolina. 31* Keystone View Company Manufacturers Copyrighted Made in U.S.A. Publishers. Meadville, Pa., New York, N.Y., Chicago, Ill., London
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Great Smoky Mountains; Views; Stereographs;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 37570 LOOKING TOWARD TENNESSEE FROM THE TOP OF CLINGMAN'S DOME, GREAT SMOKY MOUNTAINS Clingman's Dome is the topmost peak in the park. From this elevation of 6,642 feet there is an unobstructed view of timbered ridges, shared equally by North Carolina and Tennessee. Their axes run almost east and west for fifty-four miles and at no point does the area exceed nineteen miles in width. Great honor is due the naturalists who returned to untold hardships year after year in order to explore this fastness and reveal its true import to our nation. In some 700 square miles more varieties of plants have been found than in any other equal area in the temperate zone. Included in the list are all of those growing along the Atlantic from Canada to Georgia. To better comprehend the botanical wealth of the region a few figures may help. There are 129 species of trees alone. This is significant when one recalls that in all of Europe there are only eighty-five. Flowering plants contribute 1,200 varieties while fungi, mosses, lichens and liverworts add 1,600 more to the grand total. Even with all of these, the possibilities are still far from exhausted. Two hundred thousand of the 428,000 acres are covered with virgin spruce and hardwoods, the only stand of their kind left in this country. Trails or paths, spelling certain disaster to the uninitiated, are the sole means of access to this hinterland where matted luxuriant undergrowth bridges many of the streams, hiding them so completely that their presence would be undetected except for the gurgling, bubbling sounds of the water. Yes, adventure still abounds, even for those hardy individ- ualists who mutter objections as civilization makes inroads and establishes its footholds.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: There came into my possesion a group Photograph of FOUR generations consisting of the following:- John Vinson, aged 89 years born at Newport Cocke Co.Tenn.. a Great- Grand-Father # 1 in Photo F.M.Vinson, aged 63 born in Newport,Cocke County Tenn. the Grand- Father #2 in Photo Mrs E.J.Vinson, " 46 born in Cades Cove Blount county Tenn. a Grand- Mother #3 in Photo. Mrs Blanche Bond, aged 19 born in Rockford Blount Co.Tenn the Mother is #4 in Photo. R.J.Tipton, aged 79 born in Cades Cove Blount Co.Tenn. a Great-Grand- Father # 5 in Photo. Mrs E.Tipton, aged 65 born in Sevier County Tenn a Great-Grand- Mother not able to have Photo taken. Robert Bond ,aged 20 born near Louisville Blount Co Tenn,the Father is # 6 in Photo. Cecil H.Bond, aged 3 months born in Maryvilie Blount Co.Tenn # 7 Mrs Susan A. Kidd, aged 41 born near Louisville,Blount Co.Tenn,a grand- Mother #8 in Photo. Harve Kidd,aged 53 born near Rockford,Blount Co.Tenn step-Grand- Father not taken James Hicks,Esq., aged 63 born near Rockford,Blount Co.Tenn.,a Great- Grand-Father #9 in Photo. All above are alive at this date, February 3 1896 and in Blount County Tennessee, W.E. Parham, owner.

"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: SPC 2014.010.001 a
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: L.W. Keen
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: SPC 2014.010.001 a Stereograph view of the Funeral of Ex-President Andrew Johnson at Greeneville, Tenn. August 3d, 1875. Court House where the remains were Lying in State. The Hearse in front waiting for the delayed train from Knoxville. From Brown’s Building looking South-East. A series of 12 of these views taken on the same day form an interesting and comprehensive idea of the occasion. Greeneville, &c., surroundings. Published by L.W. Keen, Photographer, Jonesboro’, Tenn. SPC 2014.010.001 b back of stereograph with ID information.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thomas Legion
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cherokee Confederate veterans of Thomas's Legion at the New Orleans Confederate Convention in 1903. Shown with Confederate flag and banner.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Veterans; Group portraits; Indigenous peoples; Flags;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The following caption was under the image: Above is shown the last photograph ever taken of the remaining members of the famous Thomas Legion, composed of Cherokee Indians in the Confederate Army. The photograph was made in New Orleans at the time of the New Orleans Reunion of Confederate Veterans. The inscription on the banner, displayed in the photograph, is as follows: "Cherokee Veteran Indians of Thomas Legion. 69 N. C. Regiment. Suo-Noo-Kee Camp U. C. V. 4th Brigade, N. C. Division." Reading from left to right, those in the picture are: front row, 1 Young Deer; 2 unidentified; 3 Pheasant; 4 Chief David Reed; 5 Sevier Skitty; back row, 1 the Rev. Bird Saloneta; 2 Dickey Driver; 3 Lieut. Col. W. W. Stringfield of Waynesville; 4 Lieutenant Suatie Owl; 5 Jim Keg; 6 Wesley Crow; 7 unidentified; 8 Lieutenant Calvin Cagle. All of these men are now dead with the exception of Sevier Skitty, who lives one mile from Cherokee. Lieut. Col. Stringfield and Lieut. Cagle were white officers of the legion. Names of the men in the photograph were furnished by James R. Thomas of Waynesville, son of the late Col. W. H. Thomas,who commanded the Thomas Legion. This band of Indians built the first road across the Great Smoky Mountains.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Briscoe. W.R. Briscoe
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of W.R. (William Russell) Briscoe (1899-1979) in a military cadet uniform, possibly from Mt. Hermon School for Boys in Northfield, MA. For most of his life, Russell Briscoe lived and worked in Knoxville, TN. He joined the Marines during World War I and was stationed in Washington, D.C. He was co-owner with his wife of Bristoy toy company in the 1930s and he was an executive vice president of the J.E. Lutz Insurance Company. He began painting at age 57 and produced 75 painting, most of historic subjects in East Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a log house, later weatherboarded, built by my grandfather, James Scott, Sr. on the site of a filling station on the corner of Broadway and Lawson Streets, Knoxville, Tennessee. He was born in Ireland, and we first hear of him in Virginia, where he married Janet Adams, daughter of John and Agnes Adams. They moved to Washington County (then in North Carolina):, then to Blount County, where their first years were spent in a blockhouse, after which he built a log house on his farm which consisted of 640 acres, but at one time they were forced to return to the blockhouse, because of an Indian raid. He, with other men, fired through the portholes while Janet and other women moulded bullets on the hearth. He was an intrepid fighter, John Sevier called him his "right-hand man" when fighting the Indians. I am pretty sure he fought with John Sevier in the Battle of King's Mountain, but have never been able to prove it. He and Janet were members of the New Providence Presbyterian Church in Blount County and moved their membership September 22, 1821 to the First Presbyterian Church of Knoxville, Tennessee. James and Janet Adams Scott are buried in the old graveyard of that church. They both were born in the year 1760. He died August 30, 1823:, aged 63 years. Janet died August 10, 183 7, aged 77 years. Ramsey's Annals tells of James Scott Sr. being a representative from Blount County to the House of Representatives, and also tells of his receiving a letter from his brother-in-law, Samuel Handley (Henley). They married sisters, Samue I Henley married Mary Adams, and James Scott, Sr. married Janet Adams. Janet (more often called Jane) Adams Scott, a sprightly vivacious little soul with auburn hair, was born in Virginia, but was of Irish ancestry. Her son, James Scott, Jr. spoke of her as his "sweet little Irish mother" and said she spoke with an Irish brogue. Her experiences as a pioneer woman were ever vivid in her mind, and when telling them, she would walk the floor, dropping her knitting ball, her little grandson (my father) would pick it up, trembling with fear and excitement as she told her narrow escapes from the Indians. This picture was taken by "Sister Ret" who could draw and paint as life-like pictures as the ones she took with her camera. (continued inside)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_004 p. 1c

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Photographs; Scrapbooks; Families; History; Portraits;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: We have just seen that my great-grandfather, James Scott, Sr.., was with John Sevier in fighting the Indians, and as he was a good age at the Battle of Kings Mountain, he could have been in that engagement, but we could not prove that he fought at that time. My cousin, Roscoe C. d'Armand, a direct descendent of James Scott, Sr., is a wonderful genealogist, and he wrote me June 20, 1961 - "James Scott, Sr., served with North Carolina troops during the Revolutionary War from Captain Vail's Company, Second Regiment 1777; and again in Captain Bailey's Company 10th Regiment, for a period of 12 months from August 1, 1782. Apparently ancester James served first as a lad of 17 and again after he reached manhood and shortly before he married. It has been a long trail and a long search, done most of the time in darkness with no assurance whatever save legends that survived. Apparently he did serve with Sevier and Landon Carter, since their names both appear on his voucher". Again, August 10, 1961, he sent me all I need for a supplemental DAR paper on James Scott Sr.. JAMES SCOTT, Sr. served during the Revolutionary War, as a private from August 1, 1782, for a period of 12 months; and again as a private in Vail's Company, 2nd Regiment, from 1777 to November 1777, both in North Carolina troops. He afterward served with John Sevier in his war against the Indians and achieved the rank of Captain and then Colonel. Department of Archives and History, North Carolina Records, page 1153: 2nd Regiment Muster and page 1165: 10th Regiment Muster. Inid, Treasurer's Papers, Rev. Vochers No. 3344, June 12, 1783: The auditors for the counties of Washington and Sullivan certify that James Scott is allowed 9 pound specie as per voucher 12th of June 1783: By E. Williams - Landon Carter. John Sevier, Sec." My cousin writes "our Colonel Scott's military service is without question and the proof is there". I am indeed most happy to know my great-grandfather was a true patriot and fought for his country.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is my great grandfather's mill, which he built some time after 1815, and was almost opposite the log house, we have just seen. We are looking at the back of the mill. In front runs Broadway, and the mill sat back, perhaps two hundred feet from the road, or street it is now. Up the creek, about a long city block, James Scott, Sr. built a brick house on the west side of the creek, and this side of a big bold spring. In 1825 my grandfather, James Scott, Jr., who carried on the milling business started by his father, brought his bride Eliza Jane Naomi Bane Alexander Ramsey, to this home. On October 12, 1827 their first child (my father) was born. When he was six years old they moved across the road to a house his father built in 1833. When he was eleven years old his father died, and from that time on, he was his mother's stay and comfort and in a short time he was carrying the family and the business of the mill on his young shoulders. But with it all, managed to graduate at the Univ

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_008 p. 3a
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_008 p. 3a
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Photographs; Scrapbooks; Families; History; Houses;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is Cedar Grove, the house my grandfather, James Scott, Jr. built in 1833. The walls are solid hand- pressed brick, made on the place by his slaves. The house is ell-shaped, two stories with eight rooms, four below and four above. The chimneys are built in the end walls, and the fire places were originally wide enough to hold almost a chord of wood. In the kitchen fire place were hooks on which hung kettles and spits. The location of the house is ideal, in a grove of cedar trees, on a high knoll on the west side of First Creek and what is now Broadway. It is above a big bold spring, and because of its accessibility is why this house and the one across the road, were built. Finding a good spring was usually what decided the early settlers for a location for their homes. The place originally encompassed four hundred acres of farm land, that is now Oakwood and Lincoln Park, extending to Sharp's Ridge, also to our home site, Oak Hill, on the top of the hill above Cedar Grove, and extending beyond what is now Scott Street. This view of Cedar Grove would make a lovely painting. The picture was made after Dr. and Mrs. Ogle remodeled the house. They put electricity and water and a furnace in it, and added the stone terrace and the very beautiful doorway. There are many artistic touches in the house - the mantels are hand carved, and the shallow, broad steps, and beautifully wrought banisters of the staircase show that my grandfather and grandmother appreciated the fine and artistic. Though my grandfather was successful in carrying on his father's milling business and established the Scott Flour Mills, which were in operation for over a hundred years, and was prosperous in material things, we think of him best as a good man. He was known as "the peacemaker" for he was just that whenever any dispute arose between his friends and neighbors. In an epidemic of cholera in 1838, he died September 14 of that year, while ministering to his friends and neighbors without any regard to his own health. His marriage to Eliza Ramsey was ideally happy. They had only five years together, from 1833 to 1838 in this lovely home at Cedar Grove. My grandmother was left with five children, the youngest two years old and the oldest eleven years old. She taught them to reverence the memory of their father. Every Sunday she would take them to the First Presbyterian Church, taking a lunch and would stay for the second service, after which she would take them to their father's grave in the church graveyard, and tell them what a good, noble man was their father.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_010 p. 4a

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here is a front view of Cedar Grove. I am rather of the opinion that point in the roof was not in the original roof, but there was a straight line across, which would enhance the looks of the house very much; however, I do not know that this was a fact. When my grandfather died in 1838, my grandmother took over the management of the estate. When she died in 1858, and a division of the property had to be made, my father, being the oldest, was given his choice of what he wanted. He left the decision to my mother, who said she had no choice but that she did not want the house. She was very devoted to her mother-in-law - so much so - that when she died in January, Just three months after my mother had gone to Cedar Grove as a bride, she had no desire to live there any longer, and felt she could not bear to be where she had had such sweet relationship, that now must be at an end. The house was inherited by my Uncle Gettys, who in time sold it to a man named Saltmarsh or Softmarsh, who I think could not pay for it. It was bought by Mr. Ledgerwood, who lived there with his family for many years. After his death, Dr. and Mrs. Ogle bought the place from the Ledgerwood heirs, when it was in very bad repair. Then it was that they saw its possibilities and they completely transformed it. Then in turn, sold it to the Baptist Church, who are the present owners. We have just read that a Baptist church is the present owner of "Cedar Grove", but they abandoned it, for what reason I do not know, however, the vandals soon found the place was open for their destruction, and started in in dead earnest to destroy it, knocking out windows and doors and doing all the damage they knew how to do. But fortunately Mr., and Mrs. Stevens were looking for a place for a funeral home and saw the possibilities of "Cedar Grove" for that purpose. How glad I am that they bought it and on April 17, 1961 opened Stevens Mortuary. I am sure "Cedar Grove" was never prettier than it is today - up on a knoll in a grove of beautiful trees, with the creek flowing quietly at the foot of the knoll - accessible to Broadway, but far enough away to be very quiet. The interior is beautifully and tastefully furnished in every detail. There is where I want to be buried from not so very far away from where my marker is already placed in our family lot in "Old Gray Cemetery" - but of course all this is just if the Lord tarries.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_013 p. 5a
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_013 p. 5a
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here in the extreme left of this picture, we see a portion of a door. Let us open the door and enter the old fashioned parlor of Cedar Grove - a very large room with two windows to the south and two to the north, and a large open fire place opposite the door we are entering. As we turn to the left there is a beautiful picture on the wall so it seems, but really it is wallpaper, brought from Paris before 1833. It did not come in rolls as it does today, but in squares. Wall paper was a rare luxury in America at the time Cedar Grove was built. Little, if any, was manufactured in America, or perhaps even in England. France seemed to have the monopoly of its manufacture. Aside of its original cost, the purchaser had to pay for its transportation which was by slow sailing vessels taking months to cross the ocean - then long overland or longer river transportation - from New Orleans to Tennessee. The paper is generally referred to as hand-painted, but it is probably printed from hand engraved wood. Some of the scenes are reproduced from the Gardens of Versailles. At the time Cedar Grove was built there were only two other houses in Tennessee with paper of this character. One at the Hermitage in Nashville and the other in a home in Rogersville, which later burned. Let us continue on around the room and see it all.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_015 p. 6a

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here we have a most interesting scene. The lady and gentleman evidently started out for a walk and stopped at this inviting seat to rest. Perhaps as they took their seats they were chattering happily together-but something stirred up trouble, whoever started it, or what was the cause of it, we will never know, but we can safely guess the lady has the upper hand now. She has arisen to her feet in indignation, and her determined right arm gives strength to her argument, and she is telling him exactly where to head in. He is making a feeble effort to stay her anger, but it looks hopeless as we see the situation pictured. Let us hope they finally settled their argument or quarrel and continued on their walk, through such beautiful surroundings, conducive to more amicable conversation. Let us move on too.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_017 p. 7a
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_017 p. 7a
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here we have a love scene. The gentleman with his hand on his heart is standing before the lady of his choice pouring out his ardor and devotion. Years ago, I remember just being able to decipher the name "Lillie " written in pencil at the feet of the lady, and the name "Will" written at the feet of the gentleman. "Lillie" who was the daughter of W. B. A. Ramsey, aad a niece of my grandmother visited at Cedar Grove:, perhaps many times. "Will" was W. H. Simmons. Whoever put those pencil marks, putting those two names together, I do not know. However, they seemed to sense which way the wind would blow for later lillie and Will became Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Simmons. The lovers in the picture seem set apart, and quite oblivious to the fact that some gentlemen and ladies are being most cordially invited to enter into - perhaps a palace - by a doorman or butler, or perhaps the host himself. Are not these old scenes most fascinating!

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_019 p. 8a
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_019 p. 8a
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Now we are opposite the door where we entered the room and we see the lovely mantel. This scene pictures perhaps a picnic, where the musicians are entertaining the crowd. I imagine the violinist with the high hat, is playing a concerto - he rests his bow while the flutist is playing the cadenza. The setting is just the place to enjoy sweet music. When my sister Anne was redecorating her apartment she conceived the idea of buying this old mantel at Cedar Grove and placing it at the chimney between two windows. We all became quite excited over the idea and she wrote Dr. Ogle, who was the owner at that time, and he agreed to sell if she would put another mantel in its place. Her husband very wisely suggested that she measure the space between the windows to see if the mantel would go in, which it would not do. It measured eleven feet across and is so high that I could not reach to get anything from the top of it.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_021 p. 9a
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_021 p. 9a
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photographs and captions from Miss Edith Scott's Memory Book, started July 1957. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here we come to a boat scene. The people in one of the boats look placid, and all of them look happy, but why that could be possible, when the water is so choppy, is hard to understand. In fact, if I didn't know better, I would take that water to be plowed ground. The process of papering the walls of this large room was somewhat of a Herculean task for the paper did not come in rolls, marked so the paper-hanger could follow the markings, and so match the design. This paper came in squares, and it was more like putting together a jig-saw puzzle. The man who did this was Knoxville's first town marshal!, a French pirate from the Gulf of Mexico, named John Stacks. The story goes that he helped Andrew Jackson with the British at New Orleans, and hearing such tales of the beauties of Tennessee, from the coon-capped riflemen of General Jackson, he came with them from New Orleans to Knoxville and hung up his shingle as a paper-hanger. Let us hope that Knoxville was so law abiding that it induced him to repent of his piracy and turn to enforcing the law in the position of town marshall. However, my grandfather trusted him enough to engage him to hang this lovely paper. He evidently did an excellent job for in 1942 when Mrs. Ogle had these pictures taken, the paper had been on the walls one hundred and nine years.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_023 p. 10a
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_023 p. 10a
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here we have a part of the boat scene we have already seen. Cedar Grove was used as a hospital for the soldiers during the War Between the States, and when we consider that they cooked in this room we wonder that the walls were not blackened by smoke. If the paper on the walls could have talked it could have told us much that we would love to hear. Perhaps some stories the soldiers told one another to while away the lonely hours as they longed for home. My uncle William Scott told one thing that happened in this room. He said my grandmother believed in rearing her children according to the Bible. When one of them was guilty of some misdemeanor, she would take them in the old parlor and talk seriously of the sin they had committed, they would then get down on their knees and she would pray for them and for herself - then she would use the rod. My uncle said he never heard a word of the serious talk or the prayer for he knew what was to follow. However, he must have felt the affect of it all and evidently the prayers of the good mother were answered for he grew up to be a Christian lawyer, and an elder in the Presbyterian Church. We are loathe to leave this old parlor with its associations, but here we are at the door we entered, and we must pass out and close the door behind us and leave all the sweet memories of the past.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_025 p. 11a
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_025 p. 11a

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Now this is the same scene we had over the mantel. I shall ever be grateful that Mrs. Ogle had these pictures taken when she and Dr. Ogle were living at Cedar Grove. She said she wished the pictures could have been colored but in that case, they could not have been copied, and I would not have these lovely copies, which she most graciously had made for me. When the Baptist Church bought Cedar Grove from Dr. and Mrs. Ogle, they seemed to appreciate the beauty and historical value of the paper, but they sold it to Mrs. Thomas Berry, who had it steamed off the walls, and then gave it to the University. I wish I had known when she had it taken off for I would have liked to have bought this picnic scene, as there were two of them. I would have covered it with glass and framed it, and wouldn't it have been a sweet picture!

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here is a picture of the mantel at Cedar Grove, which Sister Ret took with her camera. My brother, John, who was an architect was really an artist in many lines. He admired this mantel very much and particularly wanted its picture. I have tried to find a picture of an open fireplace to go in it, but have not succeeded yet - but I shall keep on trying. I think it was Mr. Ledgerwood, when living in the house, plastered up the fire place in this way. I wonder if the large room could have possibily been heated with that very small grate. When Dr. and Mrs. Ogle lived there they tore this away and made an open fire place.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the small picture is the old spring house, nestling in the snow. The spring was a big, bold one and did not need the snow to keep it cold for in the hottest day in summer all perishable food was safe in its refreshing coolness.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: LANDMARK—This historic dwelling, more than a century old, is expected to be moved from Church Avenue on the proposed department store site, to a new loca- tion for preservation. Onetime home of the city founder's granddaughter, it is one of Knoxville's most aged structures, after Chisholm Tavern, Blount Mansion and the ____ ____ across State Street from the mansion. This little house is where my mother and father went to housekeeping. I do not know if it was in 1858 or 1859. My oldest sister, Elizabeth Crozier., was born June 22, 1858 at Fruit Hill, my mother's home - where she and my father were married September 24, 1857. Our next child, James Alexander., was born December 15, 1859 in this little house - so sometime in these two years my parents made the move from Cedar Grove. And in 1859 or 1860, I think it must have been, then decided to build a home and bought a lot opposite to what was then, the Deaf and Dumb Asylum, now the City Hall. This house is known as "The Bride's Gift House" and the early history is that it belonged to James White, the founder of Knoxville. His son, Hugh Lawson White, gave it to his daughter, Isabella White, as a bridal gift when she married William B. French in 1843 at the home of her aunt Mrs. Overton in Nashville. She lived in the house some time, I do not know how long, but she or somebody, rented it to my parents when they lived there in 1859. Her sons sold it to James. G. Mitchell in 1873. W. P. Toms owned it when Rich's Atlanta store bought it in the block between Clinch, Church, Henley and Locust Streets for the Rich's Knoxville store. They announced they would without charge, turn this landmark building over to any one interested in transferring it to another location for preservation. Now is my chance to live in one of the many houses I have a great interest in. IF (that great, big, awful IF) I had the money to buy a lot suitable for its location, and if I had the money to put the building material together- then wouldn't I have a darling little house! and wouldn't I love it!

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_032 p. 14a

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Photographs; Scrapbooks; Families; History; Houses;

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This place we always called 96 Asylum Street, but the street is now Western Avenue. The house at first was only one story with dining room and kitchen in the basement. The lot on which it stood was one hundred and fifty feet square. The house must have been started in 1859, 1860 or 1861. My sister, Margaretta Naomi, was born July 31, 1861 at Fruit Hill, so I do not know if we had moved to this house, or were still living in the "Bride's Gift House". We can imagine what a turbu- lant time that was with the War Between the States going on. Just when the second story with dining room and kitchen upstairs, was added to the house, I do not know, but it must have been pretty soon, for our children were coming right along, and during the Siege of Knoxville, my grandmother and grandfather came there when their home was burned in 1863; and other relatives were coming and going frequently. In the picture we were all there, except my oldest brother, James Alexander. We will start at the left: first is Frank Ramsey, born in this house May 6, 1865; next comes Anne (we always called her Annie) born July 26, 1867. Then David Deaderick, born here April 27, 1863. Next Frederick William, sitting in his mother's lap, born in this house January 6, 1876. My mother was born at "The Cottage" in Jonesboro, Tennessee. Next is my father, born in a brick house across the road from Cedar Grove, October 12, 1827. Sitting on the step is John Barton, born January 18, 1872. Sitting next to him is Mary, born here December 27, 1869. Seated is Elizabeth Crozier, born at Fruit Hill, the Deaderick home, June 22, 1858. Curled up in the chair is Edith, born here November 28, 1878. (Sister Lizzie is trying to keep me still and from talking, which is the reason she turned away and refused to respond to my calls of "Sister Rizzie"). Next is Margaretta Naomi, born at Fruit Hill, July 31:, 1861. At her feet is Clarence, born here July 16, 1874.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_034 p. 15a
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_034 p. 15a

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here is the same house we have seen, only remodeled. Several rooms added to the back, upstairs and down, and as you see, a tower added to the roof. Building a house as room is needed, certainly makes a comfortable, convenient home. Living there we knew exactly what we needed and built accordingly. The yard was just as nice as the house. We had fruit trees and lovely shrubbery. Sister Lizzie had a green thumb - flowers were her hobby. She had two pits full, and worked there and in her flower beds every day the weather would permit. My mother, too, was a great lover of flowers and worked with them. We had a stable and kept a cow, then we always had a turkey coop for we must have a turkey every Sunday for dinner and other times too. My brothers had an acting pole in the back yard, and what good times we had with that! They would let me play baseball with them, until the boys in the neighborhood would come, then I knew I must get in the house. In this picture we have all grown. Starting at the left: first is Sister Ret, with her hat in her hand; sitting down on the porch at her feet is John Barton; standing next is Frederick William. Behind the post, where you can just see her is Sister Lizzie; and seated next to her is our dear cousin Mack Stewart, who used to visit us frequently and was almost one of the family. She and Sister Lizzie were special friends. Seated next is Mamma; standing is my father; and at his feet is Clarence (Clake we always called him). Next is Annie; then I am standing with my oldest brother Jimmie, who was not in the other picture. Standing at the gate is Frank Ramsey; and seated in the buggy is David Deaderick (Buddy); and with him is Mary. Our house was well located for it was directly opposite the Deaf and Dumb Asylum, and it was just like having a park in front of us. From the back we had a view of "College Hill" - now the University of Tennessee. The three old original buildings, as we saw them, silhouetted against the sky, have long since been taken down, and so has 96 Asylum Street. Henley Street cut off the back yard, and Wall Avenue cut down the house itself.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: We have to go back many, many years for the history of this house, which we see only the front doorstep. My great-grandfather, Captain John Crozier built it on the North East corner of Gay Street and Clinch Avenue, now the site of the Farragut Hotel. I can remember when the hotel there was called the Hattie House, and was built directly in the corner of the lot, which made it almost in front of part of the Crozier home. There was a brick walk running along the North side of the hotel back to this door-step we see in the picture. For years the Crozier house was part of the hotel. I suppose it has been taken down when the present hotel was enlarged. Anyway, for many years the brick walkway has been a little narrow store - I think always a shoe store. My great-grandfather and his wife Hannah Barton Crozier lived there sumptously and entertained lavishly. Here pictured are their sons and daughters. Seated from left to right: Mary Ann (Mrs. Frank Keller); Hannah Wells (Mrs. William Swan); my grandmother, Elizabeth Jane (Mrs. David Anderson Deaderick); Margaret Barton (Mrs. J. G. M. Ramsey). Standing: John Harvey; Arthur Ramsey; Hugh Gilbreath; Carrick White. Margaret Barton was twice my great-aunt, being the sister of my grandmother Deaderick, and she was my great aunt-in-law, as she was the wife of Dr. J. G. M. Ramsey, who was the brother of my grandmother Scott. The Crozier ladies were said to be noted for their beauty and brains.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_038 p. 17a
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_038 p. 17a

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here is Fruit Hill, the home of my grandmother and grandfather Deaderick. The original Fruit Hill was the home of my great-grandparents, John and Hannah Barton Crozier, I wish very much I had a picture of it, but my mother said James Park, the father of Rev. James Park, admired it so much, he wanted to build his house just like it. I do not know how closely he carried out that desire. The Park home is still standing on the corner of Cumberland Avenue and Walnut Street. My grandmother Deaderick inherited Fruit Hill and many of her children were born there. My mother was not born there, but was married there, September 24th, 1857, her sister Anne, and two first cousins, were bridesmaids. One was Mary Elizabeth (daughter of Dr. Carrick Crozier) and Darthula (daughter of Arthur Ramsey Crozier). My mother's two sisters were also married there. Two of our children were born there,-Elizabeth Crozier and Margaretta Naomi. November 20th, 1863, Fruit Hill was burned by the Federal soldiers. When it was just about night, they gave warning to get out before they started burning the house. My grandmother, carrying a candle, tried to get as many blankets, and necessary things, as she knew would be needed at our Asylum Street house, where so many were coming in. The soldiers called to her, if she didn't put the candle out, "the Rebels" would fire on the house. She tried to conceal the lighted candle with the shawl around her shoul- ders, which made it almost impossible to get anything. My grandfather and Uncle Todie (Crozier), carried away some things in a wagon, but of course there was a great lost. All of them, including Grannie (Maria) and Elvira, two faithful slaves, slept at our house that night. The immense oak tree was injured on the side by the burning house,, as we can see in the picture. I do not know when the house was rebuilt, but certainly must not have been started until the war was over. I have sweet memories of this place, when my grandmother and Aunt Alice McClung were living there. Aunt Alice is sitting on the ground by the tree, and Charlie Irly, a little cousin of ours, is in the swing. I remember the yard extended on down the hill to the spring, and I was outdone one day, when my mother and I went out there, and a road had been cut between the house and the spring, and a fence built all around the place. I didn't like it at all,- neither did I like it, a short time ago, when a street was cut right through the house, and it is no more. So, that ever- moving progress must go on, whether we like it or not.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_040 p. 19a

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here is "The Cottage":, three and half miles from Jones- boro, Tennessee, where my mother Margaretta Frances Deaderick was born April 22, 1833. The Deaderick home in Jonesboro was called Poplar Hill, but my great-grandmother, Margaretta Anderson Deaderick and her son (my grandfather) David Anderson Deaderick, moved to The Cottage October 1828. My grandfather Deaderick married my grandmother, Elizabeth Jane Crozier, July 11, 1831, and brought her here as a bride. Their first child was not born here but at Fruit Hill, Knoxville, Tennessee. The next and only one of their children (my mother) was born in this little one-story brick house. They moved to Knoxville in 1834. When my grandmother Deaderick's parents, John Crozier died September 12, 1838, and his wife Hannah Barton Crozier, died October 11, 1838, then it was that Grandfather and Grandmother Deaderick moved to Fruit Hill, Knoxville. Many years ago my sister Annie and her daughter, Margaretta, some friends and I drove to Jonesboro just to find "The Cottage" and Margaretta took this picture. It was then owned by Susan Rogan, a descendant of Uncle Franklin Deaderick's family. It was rented to strangers and we saw only the wide hall running through the house, the floor of wide planks, the doors were very wide with lovely H hinges. You didn't have to call on your imagination to see that this house, though in bad repair, could have been a sweet place to live. When the house was built some time before 1828, it was considered an oddity on account of its construction being rather uncommon. Here again this home was torn down, I think to make way for the new road from Jonesboro to Johnson City. I want to make a trip to Jonesboro to see if I can find if there is any place there that is still called Poplar Hill. My grandfather Deaderick visited his brother Franklin and family who were living at "The Cottage" in 1869, and again spent Christmas week with them in 1870.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_042 p. 21a
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_042 p. 21a

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: For many years these two Chippendale chairs were at Swan Pond. They were made in London before 1773, and were bought by my great grandfather, John McKnitt Alexander in 1774, while a member of the provincial legislature of North Carolina, and given by him to his daughter, Margaret McKnitt Alexander. When she married Francis Alexander Ramsey - that is how the chairs came to Tennessee. They were in Swan Pond until after my great grandfather's death, then they were in Uncle Doctor's home, "Mecklenburg" where the French Broad and Holston Rivers meet. Then during the War Between the States they, with other valuables, were taken for safe keeping across the Holston River to "Riverside", the home of Uncle Doctor's daughter, Cousin Margaret Jane Dickson. After the war when Uncle Doctor and aunt Peggy came back from North Carolina, where they were refugees, the chairs were taken to their home in Knoxville, which they called "Mecklenburg Place". When Francis Alexander Ramsey died, his personal effects were sold and his children bought almost all of the things. My grandmother, Eliza Jane Naomi Bane Alexander Ramsey (Scott), bought the chairs and paid thirty- one cents for them. It seems that before Uncle Doctor's death he said the chairs should go to my grandmother, Eliza Jane Scott's oldest son, my father, Frank Alexander Ramsey Scott. In 1888, when we moved to our new home, "Oak Hill":, my mother sent for the chairs and found them in the basement of "Mecklenburg Place" holding the wash tubs. When we left Knoxville to come to Morristown, the chairs came with us, so here they are. The sampler we see in the picture was made by my grandmother, Eliza Jane Ramsey. The silver sugar bowl and goblet were never in the Ramsey homes, but were in the home of John and Hannah Barton Crozier - which was the girlhood home of Aunt Peggy Ramsey. This silver sugar bowl and goblet came from the home of my great-grandparents, John Crozier and Hannah Barton Crozier, on the corner of Gay Street and Clinch Avenue, the present site of the Farragut Hotel, Knoxville, Tennessee. When returning from a trip East, some time after 1799, my great-grandfather brought my great-grandmother a beautiful silver service of four pieces -a coffee pot, tea pot, cream pitcher and sugar bowl. I have seen the coffee pot and the tea pot, both very large, on a pedestal, with ebony handles, beautiful chasing as we see on the sugar bowl. At my great-grandmother's death, October 11, 1838, her daughter, Hannah Wells Crozier, wife of William Swan, inherited the silver service. Before her death she gave the coffee pot to her niece, Cornelia Crozier, daughter of John Harvey Crozier and his wife, Mary Williams Crozier. She sent the coffee pot to New York City to be sold, and where it is now, I do not know. The tea pot was next given to her niece, Mary Elizabeth Crozier, daughter of Dr. Carrick Crozier and his wife, Elizabeth Baker Crozier, and she gave it to her niece, Carrie Clinton as a wedding present, when she married William D. Cleage. The cream pitcher was given to her niece, Darthula Crozier, daughter of Arthur Ramsey Crozier, and his wife, Nancy Henderson, and she gave it to her niece. The sugar bowl and goblet, Aunt Hannah Swan gave to her favorite niece, my mother, daughter of Elizabeth Jane Crozier Deaderick and David Anderson Deaderick. The two pieces, the sugar bowl and goblet were never in Swan Pond, but they came from the home of Margaret Barton Crozier and were many times used by her, and doubtless by Dr. J. G. M. Ramsey when he came to see her at her home on Gay Street, Knoxville. When living there, the Crozier family lived sumptuously and entertained lavishly.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_045 p. 22a

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is our home my mother named "Oak Hill":, which was well named for it was on the highest point in Knoxville, and our yard was full of a variety of oak trees. As it was up so high we had a wonderful view from the observatory on top of the house, you just can see in the picture. The Smokies, the Cumberlands stretched out before us to the south; House Mountain to the east, and Sharp's Ridge at the north. We see a little glimpse of Sharp's Ridge in the picture. The walls of the house are of solid brick, made on our property. We used to drive out here from town to see the brick kiln, red hot, burning bricks for our house. Cedar Grove, the home built by my grandfather Scott, was also built with brick made on the place, but the difference was that our bricks were not made by slave labor. There were sixteen rooms in our house and servants' room and laundry in the yard, we were obliged to have a large house for we had a large family. We also had a large brick stable and carriage room. At the end of the porch you see a conservatory, but Sister Lizzie was such a flower lover that soon it was too small, and my father built her a green house. The group seated on the porch is my mother whom you just can see, David standing, Frank seated, Annie seated and I have on a white apron. Sister Ret is taking the picture.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_047 p. 23a
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_047 p. 23a

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two more views of Oak Hill - here we see the conservatory taken away and the green house built. The bay end to the left of the house is the library and the bay window to the right is the parlor and between them, under the porch, is the sitting room. My father is standing on the porch; my brother Frank is on horse back; Clarence is stretched out on the ground; and my brother John's dog, "Nig" is lying by him. Dan and Charlie are the horses and Conley Fields is driving the carriage. In the small picture little Margaretta is coming to welcome you, or perhaps she is watching Sister Ret take the picture. I do not know if our house was built on the exact plot of land my father inherited when the property was divided among the heirs - for the other members of the family when they wanted to sell their portion, would come to him to buy from them, which he always did. That made us "land poor" for a number of years. The first property my father sold was a block between Scott Street and Baxter Avenue, and he took the money and built Oak Hill. Again, this house is no more. St. Mary's Hospital is built all over our yard, which was a little less than eight acres.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is "Linger Longer":, our mountain summer home, at Montreat, North Carolina. It is in the Presbyterian Conference grounds, and is just the sweetest place on earth. We bought the house from Mrs. Cass, who was a member of the Chedester family. They lived in Asheville:, about eighteen miles from Montreat. Some of the young men of the family helped to build the house, which was made of logs. They called it the "Chestnut Bur", which was quite appropriate, as it looked like a little chestnut bur, up on the side of the mountain. We changed the name to Linger Longer, for we loved the place so we hated to leave it in the fall - we wanted so much to linger longer. All of our friends were of the same opinion and declared the place was well named. Just around the bend of the road is a most delightful lithia spring, coming down from way up in the mountain cold as ice. We are on North Carolina Terrace, up on the mountain - close to three thousand feet above sea, and mountains all around us. We sleep under blankets through the summer, and though it gets cold in the winter, the air is so pure, you do not seem to feel the cold too much.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_052 p. 31a
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Edith Scott Coll Memory Book_052 p. 31a
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: These two dear people, Reynolds and Naomi Alexander Ramsey, are my great-great grandparents, both born in the same year - 1736 - so long ago, yet I love and admire them as if I had really known them. My great-great grandfather, son of William Ramsey of the Manor Maske, York County, Pennsylvania, was born October 24, 1736 in New Castle Delaware. In Philadelphia September 24 , 1761 he married Naomi Alexander daughter of Francis Alexander of New Hopewell, N. J. She was born December 13, 1736 and can trace her ancestry to the kings and queens of Scotland. They moved to York County Pennsylvania and settled on Marsh Creek, owned and cultivated a farm, built a merchant mill, which supplied Washington's Army at Valley Forge, Trenton and Princeton with flour. He refused British gold for the same flour, as he knew them to be enemies of his country. He was as poor in 1781 as at the commencement of the war, and when he counted his Continental money, left on his hands, it was just a scrap of paper. His sacrifices and self denial had made him penniless but he was glad to pay that price for American liberty and independence. He said what we had heard about how soldiers crossed the Delaware River on ice, how frozen roads they traveled were marked by blood from their naked feet, were no idle tales to excite sympathy, but the real truth. He also served in the French and Indian War, Muster Roll of Richard McWilliams Company, New Castle, Delaware, December 28, 1757. He sold his farm and mills and became a citizen of Gettysburg, Pa., where his half sister, Isabella Ramsey Gettys, lived. He resided there several years, but still retained his membership in his old church at Miller Town. Summer and winter, with my great-great grandmother, Naomi, their daughter, Amelia King and her two children, he drove out there every Sabbath, to hear his old minister, Mr. Paxton. He was burgess of the town in February 1807 and on the second of that month, inflicted a fine on Shem Greble for driving a team and wagon through the town on Sunday. His two sons, F. A. Ramsey of Swan Pond, near the forks of the Tennessee River and S. G. Ramsey, minister of the Presbyterian Church at Ebenezer, Tennessee, gave such glowing accounts of East Tennessee - its towering mountains, its beautiful rivers, and mild climate, with their urgent insistence to come and live in this heavenly spot, they decided - each 71 years old - to leave Gettysburg on July 9 1807. With them were their daughter, Amelia King, her two children, their son, S.G. Ramsey and family, who had been visiting them. They arrived at Swan Pond, Tennessee on August 21, 1807. What a trip taking six weeks! The dear old people lived at Ebenezer until their son died, then they came to Swan Pond, were happy there, members of the Old Lebanon Church and are buried in its graveyard, where Ramsey generations followed them. Naomi was 77 when she died in 1813 and Reynolds was 80 when he died three years later in 1816. Two grand old people, who loved and served God, and taught their children the Bible, who to the seventh generation, rise up and call them blessed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: These two dear people, Reynolds and Naomi Alexander Ramsey, are my great-great grandparents, both born in the same year - 1736 - so long ago, yet I love and admire them as if I had really known them. My great-great grandfather, son of William Ramsey of the Manor Maske, York County, Pennsylvania, was born October 24, 1736 in New Castle Delaware. In Philadelphia September 24 , 1761 he married Naomi Alexander daughter of Francis Alexander of New Hopewell, N. J. She was born December 13, 1736 and can trace her ancestry to the kings and queens of Scotland. They moved to York County Pennsylvania and settled on Marsh Creek, owned and cultivated a farm, built a merchant mill, which supplied Washington's Army at Valley Forge, Trenton and Princeton with flour. He refused British gold for the same flour, as he knew them to be enemies of his country. He was as poor in 1781 as at the commencement of the war, and when he counted his Continental money, left on his hands, it was just a scrap of paper. His sacrifices and self denial had made him penniless but he was glad to pay that price for American liberty and independence. He said what we had heard about how soldiers crossed the Delaware River on ice, how frozen roads they traveled were marked by blood from their naked feet, were no idle tales to excite sympathy, but the real truth. He also served in the French and Indian War, Muster Roll of Richard McWilliams Company, New Castle, Delaware, December 28, 1757. He sold his farm and mills and became a citizen of Gettysburg, Pa., where his half sister, Isabella Ramsey Gettys, lived. He resided there several years, but still retained his membership in his old church at Miller Town. Summer and winter, with my great-great grandmother, Naomi, their daughter, Amelia King and her two children, he drove out there every Sabbath, to hear his old minister, Mr. Paxton. He was burgess of the town in February 1807 and on the second of that month, inflicted a fine on Shem Greble for driving a team and wagon through the town on Sunday. His two sons, F. A. Ramsey of Swan Pond, near the forks of the Tennessee River and S. G. Ramsey, minister of the Presbyterian Church at Ebenezer, Tennessee, gave such glowing accounts of East Tennessee - its towering mountains, its beautiful rivers, and mild climate, with their urgent insistence to come and live in this heavenly spot, they decided - each 71 years old - to leave Gettysburg on July 9 1807. With them were their daughter, Amelia King, her two children, their son, S.G. Ramsey and family, who had been visiting them. They arrived at Swan Pond, Tennessee on August 21, 1807. What a trip taking six weeks! The dear old people lived at Ebenezer until their son died, then they came to Swan Pond, were happy there, members of the Old Lebanon Church and are buried in its graveyard, where Ramsey generations followed them. Naomi was 77 when she died in 1813 and Reynolds was 80 when he died three years later in 1816. Two grand old people, who loved and served God, and taught their children the Bible, who to the seventh generation, rise up and call them blessed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mrs. Margaretta A, Deaderick. B. 1776-D. 1857. Married Jan. 1st, 1795. Elsewhere in this memory book we have seen the pictures of "Poplar Hill", the town house, and "The Cottage", the country house, at Jonesboro, Tennessee, and the site of the store at Cheek's Cross Roads, of my great grandfather, David Deaderick II. From the pictures we learned quite a good deal about him. Here we see how he looked. I wish we could see as well how my great grandmother, Margaretta looked. She was born May 25, 1775 at White Clay Creek, Delaware, the daughter of William and Elizabeth Inslee Adnerson. (Anderson). She was quite young during the Revolutionary War. When the British were marching to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, there was nobody at home but her mother and one of the soldiers asked her if she didn't have four sons in the Rebel Army. She answered that she had four sons in General Washington's Army. When the British were rumored approaching, a woman living near their home, who was panic stricken with the news, exclaimed, "If the British come we will all go to the washtub", and cried "what shall we do?" Margaretta's mother answered, "I don't know what you will do, but I know what I will do - and my daughters - if we come to the washtub, we will wash". The Anderson family were patriots. William Anderson, Margaretta's father, was too old to join the Army, but at the age of forty-six, he joined anyway, but died the first year of the War. When great grandmother came to visit her brother, General Joseph Anderson, who had married Only Patience Outlaw, she seemed to be a little homesick and wanted to go back home, perhaps remembering the gay, happy time when she was bridesmaid at the marriage of James Madison and the brilliant Mrs. Todd in 1794. In those days you couldn't get on the train, or in your car, or better still, fly where you wanted to go, but you had to wait weeks, months sometimes, before a suitable escort could take you. Her mother, Elizabeth Inslee Anderson, writes her she must be content to "live retired" if she comes home now, and urges her to be patient. But no, Margaretta meets the handsome David Deaderick - no more talk of going to Delaware. The next wedding she attended was her own, on January 1, 1795. It was a happy marriage for twenty-eight years, until October 20, 1823, when David Deaderick II passed away. She lived a full life when left a widow. She united with the church of Rev. Samuel Doak at Old Salem in East Tennessee before any Presbyterian church was organized in Jonesboro - then Dr. Charles Coffin preached in the Court House before the Presbyterian church was built. She was one of the five ladies who started the ladies prayer meeting which met every week and was intimately connected with the prosperity of the church. October 21, 1857 she passed away triumphantly in Christian faith.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here is another David Deaderick, son of the one we have just seen, born March 23, 1797 in Jonesboro, Tennessee, and his wife, Elizabeth Jane Crozier Deaderick, daughter of John and Hannah Barton Crozier. My grandfather was the third of the name David - only he was David Anderson Deaderick, adding his mother's maiden name. He died before I was born by several years, but I feel as if I knew him well, for his high principles and standards were instilled into his children, and my mother almost daily would speak of him - what he had said, and what would he say to the present-day way of living? There is so much to say about this just and devout man - his sweet loving nature that drew his grandchildren to his knee Immediately, his love of nature, his delight in mountain scenery. Even in later years, he made trips to the Smoky Mountains and walked twenty miles through the mountains in one day. His physical endurance was remarkable. About the year 1832 he, with other men of East Tennessee, was appointed by the State Legislature Commissioners to supervise improvements in the Tennessee River at "The Suck", and it was during this service my grandfather performed the wonderful and perilous feat never done, perhaps, before or since by any man, of swimming through that terrible whirlpool of waters, called the "Boiling Pot". He was a man absolutely without fear, but this incident he never wanted to allude to, for a man from Pennsylvania, standing by said that he "could do anything a Tennesseean could" but attempting to do the same thing, was drowned, which distressed my grandfather that he, himself, had been so rash. He loved to travel and joined the Forty Nlners on their trip to California, arriving a year and ten days after leaving Knoxville. The trip back home was quite different - his money gave out, and he did not return by overland, but came by steerage around the Cape of Good Hope, by New Orleans, and on arriving, so great and general was the joy felt at his return, that a large crowd of the population of the city met him at the wharf and escorted him to his home, where his family were hoping and wishing they could hear from him and better still, welcome him home. My mother said never was there such joy and happiness in any family. Another trip unusual for the times was to England and Scotland, taking six weeks to cross the Atlantic. He spent the winter of 1819-1820 in London, and there it was this miniature we see was made when he was 22 years old. Do you know anybody any finer looking? Elizabeth Jane Crozier Deaderick keeps pace with him. She and her sisters were noted for their beauty and brains. Much more I could tell about these two fine people. David Anderson Deaderick in 1825 was instrumental in introducing the cast iron plough in place of the old wooden mould-board article, which did more to stimulate the farmer in the improvements of the soil than any other one thing for agricultural interest in East Tennessee. He predicted we would be a manufacturing people for we had water power without end, and we would be celebrated. Hasn't the TVA proved that prediction? He was an elder, and with his wife, were members of the Presbyterian church and are buried in Old Gray Cemetery in Knoxville, Tennessee.
