oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Inslee Deaderick in Confederate uniform. This is my uncle, Ins lee Deaderick, a gallant, brave Confederate soldier, son of David Anderson and Elizabeth Jane Deaderick - the handsome couple we have just seen. My mother told us how during the siege of Knoxville Uncle Inslee was in camp near by, and he was so overcome with the desire to go home and see his mother he took the chance of being seen and caught. Alas, somebody saw him either going or coming and reported him. He was taken prisoner, and for two years suffered untold hardships at Fort Delaware. She told us the descendants of the man who reported him were then living in Knoxville, and we begged her to tell us who they were but she said no - it was all over now, and we must forgive and forget all that the soldiers and the people at home had suffered, that Uncle Inslee had no hatred or bitterness in his heart for the treatment he had received at Fort Delaware. When writing home he would leave a space in the letter where he wrote in milk or onion juice, the truth of his prison experience. The loved ones at home knew to put heat at that part of the letter, and the writing would come out plain. He made out my paper for me when I joined the UDC in 1913. He belonged to Company I, 2nd Regiment, Tennessee Cavalry, Ashby's Brigade, and added a little bit of interesting history. He stated "At the breaking up of the Army in North Carolina, General Wheeler called for volunteers to join Gen. E. K. Smith, commanding the Trans-Mississippi Department. When we got across the Mississippi River, Gen. Smith's army had surrendered and gone home no one to discharge us, so I was never parolled, nor discharged, nor surrendered." Just how was this, that he was never parolled nor discharged nor had the humiliation of surrendering? He gives the answer himself in The Confederate Veteran, May 1926, but in his extreme modesty, he leaves out the high point of the story - his swimming the Mississippi River near Memphis, Tennessee in the spring of 1865, when it was a mile or more wide, and more than a 100 feet deep, and had a current of five or six miles an hour. Just turn the page and read about it yourself.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is Dr. William Haney Deaderick, son of David Deaderick II and his first wife, Ann Knight. As I am descended from David Deaderick II and his second wife, Margaretta Anderson, this makes Dr. William Haney Deaderick my half-great uncle. He was born in Winchester, Virginia November 30, 1785, and after his mother's death when a small boy, he came with his father to Jonesboro, Tennessee. When he was ten years old his father married Margaretta Anderson, who was twenty-three years old. Though a young stepmother for a boy ten years old, she had a wonderful influence for good over him, and taught him to be a devout Christian as she reared her own children, David, Franklin, Joseph, James, Eliza Rosa and Amanda Frances. William Haney had the best of educational advantages the country afforded, and also a first-class medical education. He practiced medicine in Greeneville, Rogersville and in Jefferson County, (then in North Carolina), and later in Athens, Tennessee, where he died October 30, 1857. March 26, 1807, when he was twenty-three years old, he married Penelope Smith Hamilton, daughter of Joseph Hamilton, Sr. and Penelope Outlaw Hamilton. Eleven children were born to this union. In his second marriage he married a widow, Mrs. Lois Ashworth. One daughter was born to this union. He, like his half brothers, David and James, were at different times living at Cheek's Cross Roads, where his father had a store. At this time, 1810, when he was twenty-five years old, he performed an operation that gave him lasting fame. The medical journals gave him credit for being the first to remove the lower jaw, where an abscess had formed, and to save life, he cut the jaw bone in two at the chin, removed the trouble, replaced the bone, and saved the patient's life (who lived many years afterward). It was stated the operation was no haphazard case, but was directed by reason and judgment. Of course there was no hospital at Cheek's Cross Roads, no operating room with electric lights, no assisting surgeons nor trained nurses nor anesthetists to give an anesthetic, for there were no such things heard of. Where else could this operation have been performed but on a counter in his father's store, by a lamp and flickering candles? Above his reputation as an esteemed physician of East Tennessee and a surgeon of no mean degree, he was a man of high moral character, a high-toned and sensitive nature of deep spirituality. His death was not sudden. For many weeks he knew he would soon leave this earth and often spoke of it and said he was ready and eager to go. Just nine days before he passed away his beloved stepmother, who taught him the way to live and the way to die, passed over Jordan in Jonesboro, Tennessee. When asked was she supported in Christian faith, answered, "wonderfully, wonderfully" - and again her words were repeated in Athens, Tennessee by her stepson, when asked was he supported by Christian faith. Surely the price of a good woman, whether she is mother or stepmother, is above rubies.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Here is my great grandfather, Captain John Crozier. He received his title by being designated to represent chivalry and patriotism at the funeral of General George Washington. "Conspicuous at the head of the funeral cortege was the Company of Dragoons under the lead of Captain John Crozier". He was ever known by that appelation. His daughter, Elizabeth Jane Crozier Deaderick, writes in the Crozier family Bible that her grandfather was born in France and was one of the persecuted Huguenots who left their native country and settled in Ireland. His father, John Crozier, and his mother, Jane Armstrong Crozier, daughter of Rev. Gustavus Armstrong, were born, married and died in Knockmaknowl, Fermanaugh County, Ireland, ages 98 and 97 years. He was born May 12, 1769 and came to the United States at the age of 18. He lived with his maternal uncle, James Trooper Armstrong, in Baltimore - later moved with his uncle and family to Abingdon, Virginia. From there he came to Knoxville, Tennessee, became a partner in the mercantile business with William King. After that dissolution he continued the business and became one of the most successful business men in East Tennessee. His store on the South East corner of Market and Fourth Streets (now Cumberland and Gay) was known as "Crozier's Corner". His son-in-law, Dr. J. G M. Ramsey, said in 1853, "It was shaded by the ancient forest, and considered out of town, and for this reason many predicted failure of the proprietor, but by his attention to business, his courteous manner and integrity - he soon had one of the most successful houses in town". In the store the Post Office had a space, and he was postmaster for over 41 years. In September 1798 he received his naturalization papers, and on January 3, 1799 he married Hannah Barton at the home of Major and Mrs. Arthur Crozier - John Sevier and his family being present. He was a devoted husband. He made frequent trips to Philadelphia, and at such times he remembered his wife with lovely gifts - one time bringing her a beautiful silver service. My mother inherited the sugar bowl, which is pictured elsewhere in this book with two Chippendale chairs. My great grandfather owned a large estate, several plantations, and his home on the site where the Farragut Hotel now stands, was elegantly furnished, where hospitality was dispensed to all. General Andrew Jackson made it his headquarters when in Knoxville. You see in this memory book a picture of the front door of this home - his sons standing and daughters seated on the steps. I wish so much I had a picture of their mother, Hannah Barton Crozier, the daughter of Roger Barton, a Revolutionary soldier, and Margaret Gilbreath Barton, who acted as a scout in the Revolutionary War. Her grandfather, Thomas Barton, was also a Revolutionary soldier. On another page in this memory book is a picture of "Fruit Hill", the Crozier's country home. Turn back a few pages and read about it. Captain John Crozier was public spirited, and a most liberal contributor to every good enterprise. He was known as " the poor man's friend" always protecting the poor from injustice and oppression, and gave liberally and cheerfully to every good cause. When Blount College was changed in 1807 to East Tennessee College, he was elected a trustee. He was also a trustee in the Knoxville Female Academy. The education of young women held his special interest. He was appointed one of three commissioners to make contract and superintend the construction of the First Presbyterian Church in 1812. It was completed in 1816 and at that time there was a debt on the church which was paid off by the three commissioners. He was taken into the membership of the church February 18, 1818, and was a faithful member to the end. He died at "Fruit Hill" in the epidemic of fever in Knoxville on October 12, 1838. He rests with his wife, Hannah Barton Crozier, in the graveyard of the First Presbyterian Church. My grandmother writes in the family Bible, "He suffered little pain and died peacefully and calmly, relying fully in the merits and death of our Saviour, for a glorious resurrection".

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edith Scott Memory Book
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photographs and captions from Miss Edith Scott's Memory Book, started July 1957. Her ancestors included the Scott, Deaderick, Crozier, Ramsey, Anderson and Alexander families. Francis Alexander Ramsey Scott (1827-1909) married Margaretta Frances Deaderick (1833-1909) in 1857. They were the parents of eleven children, including daughter Miss Edith Scott (1878-1971). Caption information appears below in the Full Text field.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Photographs; Scrapbooks; Families; History;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Island Home
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McCrary & Branson, Knoxville, Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Island Home, Perez Dickinson home and farm. Part of the extensive formal gardens at "Island Home," the country estate of Col. Perez Dickinson. This is the south side of the house, looking at the carriage entrance and bird house, and toward the fine smoke house which shows in the background. The carriage house and smoke house were both on the same side of the house, which was on the river side. The people are Cowans and Rheas which were all members of Col. Dickinson's family. The little girl in sunbonnet, just to the left of the old workman, is Miss Bella Cowan who was later to marry Dr. Robert M. Rhea. She was the mother of the owner of this picture (Mrs. Fayette Van Deventer). Taken about 1887. Caption by Mrs. Fayette Van Deventer.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1865 4-part view with numbers_001
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: T.M. Schleier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic photograph (in 4 parts) taken of Knoxville, Tennessee in 1865 by T.M. Schleier. Numbers were added and correspond with identifications provided by John S. Van Gilder in 1936.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Panoramic photographs; Historic buildings;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph was taken the year the War Between The States was over, 1865. Mr T.M. Schleier took it from a hill on the South Knoxville side of the river. This photograph runs from Fort Sanders on the extreme left end, acroes Knoxville, and up to Reservoir Hill on extreme right end. The numbers below, explain the places beside same numbers on pictures: 1. Fort Sanders hill. Microscope reveals deadly network of trenches. 392 Confederate soldiers fell in action here in 20 minutes. 2. Probably the original cabin of Governor Blount, on Mead's Island, near the big spring now used by the U. T. Power Plant. 3. A residence for University professors. Had a Greek temple columned front facing present Cumberland Ave. Kappa Alpha Fraternity House at one time. Today, the Administration Building is on this site. 4. East Tennessee University: West College, Old College, East College. Closed up like a clam during the war. Now the site of Ayres Hall. 5. Actual trenches of Union soldiers. "The Hill" was called Fort Byington during the war. 6. The White House. Called the Prep Building. Used as a Preparatory Department for East Tennessee University. Subsequently, the site of President Ayres home. Now the site of Ferris Hall. 7. Soldier tents pitched on present site of Library at University of Tennessee. 8. Janney House. Stood on site of present Humes Hall. Greek temple front to balance 3. Likewise originally intended as a residence for University professors. The present west end of Humes Hall may possibly consist of this building, worked over. An architectural study of this photograph, while standing beside Humes Hall, seems to indicate it. Sigma Alpha Epsilon Fraternity was at one time on first floor of Humes Hall. 9. Stone piers of bridge for unfinished Knoxville and Charleston Railroad. Now called the Maryvllle Bridge. River was in 1865 known as the Holston River. 10. The Hugh A. M. White home. The Rodgers family lived here, Now the site of the Home Economics Building of the University of Tennessee. 11. The William S. Mead residence. Note summerhouse. Now Terry Court Apts. 12. House where Admiral Farragut lived, northwest corner Poplar and Spring Streets. Still standing. 13. The home of Mr. James H. Cowan. Subsequently owned by Mr. E. J. Sanford. Latterly, the Kappa Sigma Fraternity House in Maplehurst Park.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1865 4-part view with numbers_002
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: T.M. Schleier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic photograph (in 4 parts) taken of Knoxville, Tennessee in 1865 by T.M. Schleier. Numbers were added and correspond with identifications provided by John S. Van Gilder in 1936.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Panoramic photographs; Historic buildings;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 14. The old Ramsey house. Situated on Loudon Hill. Subsequently, the home of Mrs. Eliza J. McClung. Latterly known as the major R. C Jackson residence. Located at the present corner of Forest Avenue and 11th Street. 15. Mystery! An unknown building!! Possibly a barracks or factory. 16. Home of the dentist Dr. John Fouche on West Hill Avenue in 1859. Probably built by him. Successively occupied by Mr. Michael Gordy, then by Mr. James D. Cowan, and subsequently became a Catholic Convent with large golden cross on top. Afterwards was owned by Mr. Alex. A. Arthur. Latterly the home of Mr. Dan M. Rose. How the property of the United Daughters of the Confederacy. 17. The present site of the Sigma Nu Fraternity House. In 1865, it was the garden of Mr. Charles J. McClung. Note: The gigantic hackberry tree, now prominent at this corner, was not there 71 years ago. 18. The home of Mr. Charles J. McClung. Subsequently Mr. R. P. Gettys's residence. Today, a part of the Church Street M. E. Church lot. 19. The original Judge Sam T. Logan home. Afterwards torn down and another Judge T. Logan residence was built on corner, Just to right. 20. The famous East Tennessee Female Institute, surrounded by fragrant white locust trees, and where many of Khoxville 's present prominent matrons learned readin', 'ritin', and 'rithmetic. Over the roof of the Institute they gaily played the ball game "Anthony Over". A Knoxville girl found 600 four leaf clovers in the Institute yard one year. Now the location of the Church Street M. E. Church entrance on Henley Street. 21. Probably the old Tan Yard building and the Rolling Mill. Just to the left can be seen the little Asylum Street bridge crossing over Second Creek. 22. Rev. Robert Burns McMullen's home. Located Just above northwest corner of present Western Avenue and Broadway. He was the pastor of the First Presbyterian Church for the 18 years previous to Dr. Park. 23. Judge Robert J. McKinney's home with garden in rear. Present location of the McKinney Terrace Apartments and the Valencia Apartments. 24. The Gas Works. Demolished roof is said to be the result of cannon ball fired during war. Trellis, to left, is metal framework for gas tank. 25. Evidently, this photograph was made on a Monday. See the washing? 26. Tree's shadow indicates sun in West and photograph made in afternoon. 27. Probably the tragic tree on which Confederate Abner Baker was hanged. 28. Col. Perez Dickinson's house. Rear view. Now, Mrs. C. B. Atkin's home. 29. Roof of Deaf and Dumb School. Rev. Robert Burns McMullen was first President. Organized 1844. Now Knoxville's Civic Center. 30. The Jail! Stood on the site of the First Baptist Church on West Main Avenue! Jail was in English castle style. Huge white stockade ran around the edifice. Subsequently, Mr. Charles J. McClung built his home on this site. Latterly it was Mrs. Jacob L. Thomas's residence.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1865 4-part view with numbers_003
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: T.M. Schleier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic photograph (in 4 parts) taken of Knoxville, Tennessee in 1865 by T.M. Schleier. Numbers were added and correspond with identifications provided by John S. Van Gilder in 1936.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Panoramic photographs; Historic buildings;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 31. Mr. V. Burger's house. Built of brick taken from the original brick First Presbyterian Church, when it vas torn down. 32. The J. A. Rayl house. Today standing at corner of Main Avenue and Walnut Street. It is on the southeast corner. 33. Mr. Frank H. McClung's home at southwest corner Cumberland Avenue and Walnut Street. , This lot is now a part of the Post Office site. 34. Dr. James Park's residence First bricks laid for a John Sevier home. Now standing at southeast corner of Cumberland Avenue and Walnut Street. 35. Summit House. Hotel on Summit Hill. Mr. John C. Ristine, Proprietor. 36. Catholic Church. Quaint stone edifice. Charming. Faced West. 37. Second Presbyterian Church on Clinch Avenue. Now Schriver Brothers site. 38. Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church. White. Brick. On Church Street. 39. South end of the Market House. 40. The Terry house. Knoxville's Mayor Joe King, who at one time ran Montvale Springs, owned it before the Terrys. Now Mrs. Irwin's Dining Boom opposite the Lawson MsGhee Library. 41. The Court House. On site of present Car Barn on West Main Avenue. Clock tower, western end, and one white column plainly visible. 42. The Franklin House. On present Court House site. Back view. Formerly, this hotel had been known as the Mansion House. Solid silver tableware. 43. Steamboat landing on Holston River. Warehouse on bank above river bank. 44. Gay Street ending at Front Street. No bridge across river here in 1865. 45. The Judge Oliver Perry Temple home. Childhood residence of Miss Mary Boyce Temple. Subsequently occupied by Mr. Matthew Nelson. Location is at southwest corner of Gay Street and West Hill Avenue. 46. Chimney and white end of the Matthew Nelson and Miss Sally Jones double house. It was on the site of the present Court House lot. 47. Roof of Lamar House, This hotel was formerly called the Coleman House. Union General William P. Sanders, of Fort Sanders fame, died in the Lamar House. It is now called the LeConte Hotel. 48. Probably the white tower of the First Baptist Church on Gay Street, the steeple of which became unsafe and had to be taken down. One gentleman was nearly killed by a falling timber, which hit him, during the process. 49. Cowan, Dickinson & Co. building, and subsequently Perez Dickinson & Co. building, at northeast corner of Main Avenue and Gay Street. Building still there. Now occupied by Elgin Drug Store Inc. A commercial landmark. 50. Sam T. Atkin house. 51 Chisholm Tavern. 52 Bell House (hotel!) roof and chimneys. 53 Blount Mansion in trees. 54 First Presbyterian Church side view. 55 Monument in corner of First Presbyterian Church cemetery.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1865 4-part view with numbers_004
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: T.M. Schleier

oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
continued. 56 Mrs. Jane Kennedy's house, an L of which was Central James White's original log cabin and which was the first human habitation ever built on the site of Knoxville. Built 1786. 57. Probably rows of soldier cabins. They are located on the hillside, across the river, and opposite our present Court House, in South Knoxville. This hill, during the war, was surmounted by Fort Stanley. 58. The "Military Bridge". It ran from State Street across the river. Note its log crib piers. There was also a "Pontoon Bridge", during the war, which ran from present Central Avenue across the river. In 1865, there was not any bridge at Gay Street running across the river. 59. Site where Governor Blount signed the famous "Treaty of Holston" with 41 Cherokee Indian chiefs and before 1200 Indians in 1791. 60. First Creek emptying into the Holston Biver. Central Avenue first called Water Street is seen to the left. 61. John G. MsClannhan Flour and Grist Mill on First Creek and Main Street. Subsequently the Spot McClung Feed Mill. Now Dempster Ma.chine Shops. 62. Long white covered bridge over First Creek at Cumberland Street. 63. David R. Richarduon's and E. J. Sanford's Saw Mill and Lumber Yard on First Creek. 64. Little bridge at Clinch Street running over First Creek. 65. Scott and Dempster Flour Mill building in recent years. 66. The residence of Mr. John S. Van Gilder on East Clinch Street. 1861. 67. Home of Mr. William S. Kennedy. Now known as the "Hunter House." 68. Parson Brownlow's home. White western end peeping out from behind tree. 69. Knoxville Soap Factory. 70. Knoxville Pork House. Slaughter House. 71. Flint Hill with trail of East Hill Street running along the top of it. 72. The home, at one time, of Dr. Burnett and his wife Frances Hodgson Burnett, who wrote the book "Little Lord Fauntleroy". Mr. William S. Mead, who it is said was interested in her literary success, kindly opened his library to her. Tradition reports that she picked blackberries to get postage stamps to mall her manuscripts to publishers. 73. Temperance Hill. Fort Huntington Smith was up here during the war. 74. The John McKee house. McKee Street was named for Mr. John McKee. 75. Temperance Hall. A Methodist Episcopal Mission on the corner of Clinch Street and Temperance Street. During the war it was converted into a prison for holding captured soldiers. See the white stockade around it? Today, this building is called Gray Terrace. By John S. Van Gilder
December 2nd. 1936.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1865 4-part view with numbers ID_001
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: T.M. Schleier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic photograph (in 4 parts) taken of Knoxville, Tennessee in 1865 by T.M. Schleier. Numbers were added and correspond with identifications provided by John S. Van Gilder in 1936.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Panoramic photographs; Historic buildings;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph was taken the year the War Between The States was over, 1865. Mr T.M. Schleier took it from a hill on the South Knoxville side of the river. This photograph runs from Fort Sanders on the extreme left end, acroes Knoxville, and up to Reservoir Hill on extreme right end. The numbers below, explain the places beside same numbers on pictures: 1. Fort Sanders hill. Microscope reveals deadly network of trenches. 392 Confederate soldiers fell in action here in 20 minutes. 2. Probably the original cabin of Governor Blount, on Mead's Island, near the big spring now used by the U. T. Power Plant. 3. A residence for University professors. Had a Greek temple columned front facing present Cumberland Ave. Kappa Alpha Fraternity House at one time. Today, the Administration Building is on this site. 4. East Tennessee University: West College, Old College, East College. Closed up like a clam during the war. Now the site of Ayres Hall. 5. Actual trenches of Union soldiers. "The Hill" was called Fort Byington during the war. 6. The White House. Called the Prep Building. Used as a Preparatory Department for East Tennessee University. Subsequently, the site of President Ayres home. Now the site of Ferris Hall. 7. Soldier tents pitched on present site of Library at University of Tennessee. 8. Janney House. Stood on site of present Humes Hall. Greek temple front to balance 3. Likewise originally intended as a residence for University professors. The present west end of Humes Hall may possibly consist of this building, worked over. An architectural study of this photograph, while standing beside Humes Hall, seems to indicate it. Sigma Alpha Epsilon Fraternity was at one time on first floor of Humes Hall. 9. Stone piers of bridge for unfinished Knoxville and Charleston Railroad. Now called the Maryvllle Bridge. River was in 1865 known as the Holston River. 10. The Hugh A. M. White home. The Rodgers family lived here, Now the site of the Home Economics Building of the University of Tennessee. 11. The William S. Mead residence. Note summerhouse. Now Terry Court Apts. 12. House where Admiral Farragut lived, northwest corner Poplar and Spring Streets. Still standing. 13. The home of Mr. James H. Cowan. Subsequently owned by Mr. E. J. Sanford. Latterly, the Kappa Sigma Fraternity House in Maplehurst Park.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1865 4-part view with numbers ID_002
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: T.M. Schleier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic photograph (in 4 parts) taken of Knoxville, Tennessee in 1865 by T.M. Schleier. Numbers were added and correspond with identifications provided by John S. Van Gilder in 1936.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Panoramic photographs; Historic buildings;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: To use photographs or to order reproductions, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8808. Please refer to Image Number if available and provide a brief description of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 14. The old Ramsey house. Situated on Loudon Hill. Subsequently, the home of Mrs. Eliza J. McClung. Latterly known as the major R. C Jackson residence. Located at the present corner of Forest Avenue and 11th Street. 15. Mystery! An unknown building!! Possibly a barracks or factory. 16. Home of the dentist Dr. John Fouche on West Hill Avenue in 1859. Probably built by him. Successively occupied by Mr. Michael Gordy, then by Mr. James D. Cowan, and subsequently became a Catholic Convent with large golden cross on top. Afterwards was owned by Mr. Alex. A. Arthur. Latterly the home of Mr. Dan M. Rose. How the property of the United Daughters of the Confederacy. 17. The present site of the Sigma Nu Fraternity House. In 1865, it was the garden of Mr. Charles J. McClung. Note: The gigantic hackberry tree, now prominent at this corner, was not there 71 years ago. 18. The home of Mr. Charles J. McClung. Subsequently Mr. R. P. Gettys's residence. Today, a part of the Church Street M. E. Church lot. 19. The original Judge Sam T. Logan home. Afterwards torn down and another Judge T. Logan residence was built on corner, Just to right. 20. The famous East Tennessee Female Institute, surrounded by fragrant white locust trees, and where many of Khoxville 's present prominent matrons learned readin', 'ritin', and 'rithmetic. Over the roof of the Institute they gaily played the ball game "Anthony Over". A Knoxville girl found 600 four leaf clovers in the Institute yard one year. Now the location of the Church Street M. E. Church entrance on Henley Street. 21. Probably the old Tan Yard building and the Rolling Mill. Just to the left can be seen the little Asylum Street bridge crossing over Second Creek. 22. Rev. Robert Burns McMullen's home. Located Just above northwest corner of present Western Avenue and Broadway. He was the pastor of the First Presbyterian Church for the 18 years previous to Dr. Park. 23. Judge Robert J. McKinney's home with garden in rear. Present location of the McKinney Terrace Apartments and the Valencia Apartments. 24. The Gas Works. Demolished roof is said to be the result of cannon ball fired during war. Trellis, to left, is metal framework for gas tank. 25. Evidently, this photograph was made on a Monday. See the washing? 26. Tree's shadow indicates sun in West and photograph made in afternoon. 27. Probably the tragic tree on which Confederate Abner Baker was hanged. 28. Col. Perez Dickinson's house. Rear view. Now, Mrs. C. B. Atkin's home. 29. Roof of Deaf and Dumb School. Rev. Robert Burns McMullen was first President. Organized 1844. Now Knoxville's Civic Center. 30. The Jail! Stood on the site of the First Baptist Church on West Main Avenue! Jail was in English castle style. Huge white stockade ran around the edifice. Subsequently, Mr. Charles J. McClung built his home on this site. Latterly it was Mrs. Jacob L. Thomas's residence.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 31. Mr. V. Burger's house. Built of brick taken from the original brick First Presbyterian Church, when it vas torn down. 32. The J. A. Rayl house. Today standing at corner of Main Avenue and Walnut Street. It is on the southeast corner. 33. Mr. Frank H. McClung's home at southwest corner Cumberland Avenue and Walnut Street. , This lot is now a part of the Post Office site. 34. Dr. James Park's residence First bricks laid for a John Sevier home. Now standing at southeast corner of Cumberland Avenue and Walnut Street. 35. Summit House. Hotel on Summit Hill. Mr. John C. Ristine, Proprietor. 36. Catholic Church. Quaint stone edifice. Charming. Faced West. 37. Second Presbyterian Church on Clinch Avenue. Now Schriver Brothers site. 38. Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church. White. Brick. On Church Street. 39. South end of the Market House. 40. The Terry house. Knoxville's Mayor Joe King, who at one time ran Montvale Springs, owned it before the Terrys. Now Mrs. Irwin's Dining Boom opposite the Lawson MsGhee Library. 41. The Court House. On site of present Car Barn on West Main Avenue. Clock tower, western end, and one white column plainly visible. 42. The Franklin House. On present Court House site. Back view. Formerly, this hotel had been known as the Mansion House. Solid silver tableware. 43. Steamboat landing on Holston River. Warehouse on bank above river bank. 44. Gay Street ending at Front Street. No bridge across river here in 1865. 45. The Judge Oliver Perry Temple home. Childhood residence of Miss Mary Boyce Temple. Subsequently occupied by Mr. Matthew Nelson. Location is at southwest corner of Gay Street and West Hill Avenue. 46. Chimney and white end of the Matthew Nelson and Miss Sally Jones double house. It was on the site of the present Court House lot. 47. Roof of Lamar House, This hotel was formerly called the Coleman House. Union General William P. Sanders, of Fort Sanders fame, died in the Lamar House. It is now called the LeConte Hotel. 48. Probably the white tower of the First Baptist Church on Gay Street, the steeple of which became unsafe and had to be taken down. One gentleman was nearly killed by a falling timber, which hit him, during the process. 49. Cowan, Dickinson & Co. building, and subsequently Perez Dickinson & Co. building, at northeast corner of Main Avenue and Gay Street. Building still there. Now occupied by Elgin Drug Store Inc. A commercial landmark. 50. Sam T. Atkin house. 51 Chisholm Tavern. 52 Bell House (hotel!) roof and chimneys. 53 Blount Mansion in trees. 54 First Presbyterian Church side view. 55 Monument in corner of First Presbyterian Church cemetery.
